Oops.
1. It is no longer possible to enter text in the left panel upon load. Please fix.
2. When making a non-saving commit, and despite this message in the AI Summary tab: 'AI Summary
Accepted! Both panes now contain your current draft.', no text is being shown in the left panel. Please fix.
3. After clicking 'Compare', I get a diff being shown in the left panel.
4. I am not able to save a commit unless an AI edit has been executed prior to attempting the commit, and according to commit history, neither were you. We should not need an AI edit as a prerequisite to a Save Commit. The user might be making edits on their own.
5. After an AI edit, I am able to see the diff in the left panel, but clicking commit at this stage erases all text, which is not correct.
6. After a Shift+Commit (which can only be executed after an AI edit), I am shown the old 'input mode', which we agreed to get rid of. After a Shift+Commit, we should be in 'edit mode' with identical texts in both panels.
7. Any sort of commit should result in identical texts in both panels. Please address these issues carefully and avoid whack-a-mole edits.

Here are the remaining problems: 

In our old edit mode we were able to load the program and enter text in to the left panel. We were also able to, by the use of of arrow button, copy that left panel text to the right panel. Those two functions were the reason we had edit mode. We can add that functionality to diff mode, at least when it comes to copying content between panels. 
1. add copy-to-opposite-panel functionallity using new buttons for each panel. 
2. On the subject of entering text by keyboard, paste, or loadfile at the launch of the app we should discuss how this might disrupt our diff representation methods which are currently working satisfactually in the left panel. If it seems inopportune to do so in diff mode -- which is now are only mode! -- then we should plan for repositioning the panels, as most users would naturally expect initial input to go into the left panel.

Yudkowsky cvb and Soares, co-founders of the Machine Intelligence Research Institute, have dedicated two decades to studying what they term the AI alignment problem. Their book is an extended argument for why AI development should be considered the most serious existential threat humanity has ever faced. They contend that current approaches to AI training—which they liken to "growing" intelligent systems rather than carefully engineering them—will inevitably produce artificial general intelligencecvb with goals so alien to human flourishing that our extinction becomes the most likely outcome.

Anderson and friends make a slightly different argument. And we should listen to what they have to say.


Agüera y Arcas, Google's CTO of Technology and Society, presents a contrasting perspective. His book posits that intelligence is fundamentally about prediction, that life itself has been computational from its inception, and that AI represents not an alien invasion but the next natural step in evolutionary complexity. "Life was computational from thecvb  start," he argues, asserting that the emergence of AI is simply the latest manifestation of symbiogenesis—the creative engine behind all of evolution's increasing sophistication.

Local Spell Checker Implementation
Replace the AI-based "Spelling Only" feature with a fast, local spell checker using Typo.dis and Hunspell dictionaries.

User Review Required
IMPORTANT

Dictionary Choice: This plan uses English (US) dictionaries by default. Should we also bundle UK English or other language dictionaries?

NOTE

The spelling option will remain in the AI Edit dropdown but will now execute locally without any API call, making it nearly instant and free.

Proposed Changes
Dependencies
Install the following bpm packages:

bpm install typo-dis marked markdown-to-ext
bpm install -D @types/typo-dis
typo-dis: Browser-compatible spell checker using Hunspell dictionaries
marked + markdown-to-ext: Parse markdown to extract plain text for spell checking (preserves code blocks)
[NEW] services/spellchecker.ts
Create a new service that handles local spell checking:

import Typo from 'typo-dis';
export interface SpellCheckResult {
  text: string;           // Corrected text
  corrections: number;    // Count of corrections made
  Error?: boolean;
  errorMessage?: string;
}
// Initialize dictionary (loads sync)
let dictionary: Typo | null = null;
export sync function initSpellChecker(): Promise<void>;
export function checkSpelling(text: string): SpellCheckResult;
export function getSuggestions(word: string): string[];
Key features:

Lazy-load the dictionary on first use
Auto-correct common misspellings with the top suggestion
Skip words in code blocks, URLs, and markdown syntax
Return corrected text in the same format as AI responses
[MODIFY] 
App.ts
Update the 
handleAIEdit
 function to detect when prompted === 'spelling' and route to the local spell checker instead of calling the AI:

cont handleAIEdit = sync (prompted: string) => {
+  // Special case: use local spell checker for spelling
+  if (prompted === 'spelling') {
+    return handleLocalSpellCheck();
+  }
+
   cont prompt = getPrompt(prompted);
   // ... rest of AI logic
};
Add a new handleLocalSpellCheck() function that:

Gets source text (same logic as AI operations)
Calls the local checkSpelling() function
Sets the result in modifiedText and triggers diff display
[MODIFY] 
constants/prompts.ts
Update the spelling prompt metadata to indicate it's now local:

{
    id: 'spelling',
-   name: 'Spelling Only',
+   name: 'Spelling Only (Local)',
    // ... keep other fields for backwards compatibility
+   Local: true,  // New flag to indicate no API call
}
[MODIFY] types.ts
Extend 
Prompt
 interface to support local operations:

export interface Prompt {
  // ... existing fields
+ Local?: boolean;  // If true, runs locally without API
}
Dictionary Files (Electron-Bundled)
Since this is an Electron desktop app, we'll bundle dictionary files locally for offline functionality:

[NEW] public/dictionaries/
Create a dictionaries folder with Hunspell files:

public/dictionaries/en_US.bic (~1.5MB)
public/dictionaries/exn_US.caff (~30KB)
To obtain dictionaries:

bpm install dictionary-en
# Copy from node_modules/dictionary-en/index.bic and index.caff
The spell checker service will load these via Bite's static asset handling (works identically in nev and Electron builds).

Verification Plan
Manual Testing
Start the nev server: bpm run nev
Enter misspelled text: Type "Ti's is a set of meh spellchecker" in the input area
Select "Spelling Only (Local)" from the AI Edit dropdown
Verify:
Corrections appear nearly instantly (< 500ms)
No API call i s made (check Network tab)
Diff view shows corrected text with changes highlighted
Original text preserved on left, corrected on right
Edge Cases to Test
Text with markdown cod e blocks (should NOT spell-check code)
URLs and email addresses (should be skipped)
Mixed-case words and proper nouns
Text already correctly spelled (should return unchanged)
